title: 114_s2134
content: The "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience and a degree in a health-related field. The pilot program aims to train former Armed Forces members as physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have a degree in a health-related field, medical or military health experience, and not hold a doctorate in medicine, osteopathy, or dentistry. The program will run for five years, with at least 250 individuals selected by the Secretary, giving priority to those with relevant experience. The Secretary will prioritize individuals for the pilot program who participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program or agree to work as a physician assistant in underserved communities with a high veteran population. The Secretary will provide educational assistance, including scholarships, for individuals in the pilot program to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies. At least 35 scholarships will be given each year. The obligated service period is also specified. The pilot program requires individuals to agree to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. The length of service is determined based on the program through which the individual is participating. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. Participants who fail to fulfill this obligation will be liable to repay the amount received under the program, with exceptions for specific program requirements. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration for a specified period of obligated service. The Secretary will ensure mentors are available for participants, and seek partnerships with accredited institutions offering master's degree programs in physician assistant studies. The pilot program requires individuals to work as physician assistants for the Veterans Health Administration. Institutions offering programs in physician assistant studies must guarantee seats for participants and provide admissions information. Other support includes the Transition Assistance Program, Veterans' Employment and Training Service, and marketing programs for veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services to oversee, recruit, and assist individuals participating in the pilot program. The Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, a physician assistant and veteran, is responsible for coordinating the needs of the pilot program and providing mentors to participants. They also coordinate staff at Veterans Health Administration facilities. The pilot program includes a recruiter who reports to the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, and an administrative assistant who assists with administrative duties at a medical center of the Department. The pilot program in the Office of Physician Assistant Services includes an administrative assistant who assists with administrative duties to ensure effective operations. A report on the program's effectiveness in improving eligible individuals' ability to become physician assistants will be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The pilot program aims to enable individuals with medical skills gained in the Armed Forces to enter the physician assistant workforce of the Department and help address the shortage of physician assistants. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs, Labor, Defense, and Health and Human Services will identify necessary modifications to meet these goals. Additionally, an assessment will be conducted to determine if the pilot program can be a model for other Department programs assisting individuals in obtaining certification and employment in healthcare fields. The pilot program aims to assist individuals with medical skills from the Armed Forces to enter the physician assistant workforce of the Department of Veterans Affairs. Not less than $8,000,000 of the funding for the program will come from existing Department of Veterans Affairs appropriations. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for educating and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for educating and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes holding medical center directors accountable for utilizing these programs and incentives to advance employees' education as physician assistants and improve recruitment and retention. Additionally, the Education Debt Reduction Program will be available for participants. The Education Debt Reduction Program is available for participants in the pilot program to fill vacant physician assistant positions at the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes informing applicants of their eligibility and creating programs to encourage employees to apply to accredited physician assistant programs. Compliance with educational assistance programs is monitored to ensure full utilization. The Education Debt Reduction Program aims to fill vacant physician assistant positions at the Department of Veterans Affairs by encouraging employees to apply to accredited programs through regulations set by the Secretary. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement for competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs and the requirement for competitive pay. It includes amendments to ensure competitive pay for physician assistants and the implementation of a national strategic plan for their retention and recruitment. The Secretary must submit a report on the implementation of the national strategic plan for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs.
